intro: Syncretocarpus ancashino, commonly known as the Cashino Caper, is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the Capparaceae family and is characterized by its small, yellowish flowers and woody stems. The plant produces small, round fruits that are typically green when mature. It thrives in dry, rocky soils and is often found in high-altitude environments. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and somewhat obscure species in botanical studies.
